result.execSummary:
The defendant David L Lovell was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. David L Lovell is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • David L Lovell was found guilty of Possession of Child Pornography, a class D felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.12(1m).
  • David L Lovell was found guilty of Possession of Child Pornography, a class D felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.12(1m).
  • David L Lovell was found guilty of Possession of Child Pornography, a class D felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.12(1m).
  • David L Lovell was found guilty of Possession of Child Pornography, a class D felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.12(1m).
  • David L Lovell was found guilty of Possession of Child Pornography, a class D felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.12(1m).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Defendant is not eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program.  Defendant is not eligible for the Substance Abuse Program.

superMiscConds.notes: $1518 to be collected by the Dept of Corrections.
Def may not use any computers w/o prior written consent of agent. Any internet usage must be monitored.

Sex offender registry required. Defendant shall complete a risk and needs assessment and comply with care plan goals related to prioritized need areas identified.  Any other conditions DOC, Probation/Parole Department may impose.  Defendant advised of requirement to provide DNA sample.

DDA consents to waiver of jury. Def to enter stipulated facts agreement- to preserve Def's appellate rights. Reporter: Heather Kieta, Motion Hearing 7/29/16

Atty Eisenberg made argument re: motion to suppress.  Discussion of P2P network; court is unsure how that works in investigations.  Atty Maas planned to argue suffieciency of affidavit today only.  Atty Eisenberg would like to raise expert testimony re: definition of "pubescent" .  Atty Maas - argumetn re: P2P network (par.34) argued in support of probable casue; concedes that "pubescent" could mean somoen over 18.  Parties stipulate to chronology in affidavidt re: P2P networks made by Atty Maas and related case law.  Atty Maas clarified to court how investigator's software functions; ATty Eisenberg disagreed w/the description of the affidavit.  Continued argumetn re: interpretation of par. 34 by both counsel.  Atty . Maas objects to court's analysisa dn believes hrg shoyuld be confined to what is in the affidavit.  Ct. granted Atty Eisenbergs's request for intorduction of evidence.  Atty. Eizenberg summarized the content of his expert witness's testimony.  Expert witness Joseph Henricks sworn & testified.  Ex. 1 marked and received. Ex. 2 marked and received.  Cross examination by Atty Maas.  Ex.3 marked, Ex. 4 marked.  Redirect by Atty Eisenberg.  Recross by Atty Maas. Witness excused. Hearing adjourned.  Briefing schedule determined.

AMENDED SIGNATURE BOND - CONDITIONS MODIFIED
Your signature bond is set in the amount of $500 per case. You may be responsible for paying this amount if you miss a court date or do not follow conditions of your release.
- Defendant shall not have any contact with juvenile females unless it is supervised by a responsible adult.
- Defendant shall not access the internet.
- Defendant is only allowed to use a computer that is not connected to the internet in order to do homework associated with this treatment with Dr James Gerndt.
Trial Judge -  Br 5
regarding bond
Bail/bond hearing at 02-10-2016 09:30 am
to modify bond condition

Defn's motion to deterimine that a mandatory minimum is not required.  Argument by Atty Eisenberg regardign interpretation of Wis. Stat. 939.617 and it is being ambiguous.  ADA Sattler made argument for State's position.  Ct. finds stat. 939.617 is ambiguous.  Atty Eisenberg argues ct. needs to use rule of lenity.  ADA Sattler argues against rule of lenity. Ct. finds that intention of legislature was mandatory minimum on 948.12(1m) is 3 years.  Therfore, using the rule of lenity is not appropriate. Atty Eisenberg raises issue of discovery logs being provided by State.  ADA Sattler argues that logs were provided based on original order to do so.  Atty Eisenberg argues logs are still missing of which were referenced in warrant.  ADA Sattler argues that all logs requested and obtained have been turned over to defense.
State's brief and apendix in response to defns motion regarding WIS. STAT. 939.617

Reporter: Heather Kieta
on Defendant's motion to suppress - Atty Sattler asserted the State did not issue any charges for images recovered from the Defendant's thumbdrive and would not be using it at trial; Defendant's motion for discovery - counsel had reached an agreement as to Items 1, 3 and 5; counsel still working on an agreement as to Item 2; Atty Sattler advised the State has complied with Item 4 and will confer with DCI but thinks they can comply with Item 6; Court instructed Atty Sattler to contact DCI to see if the information requested in Item 8 can be obtained and if so, ordered her to turn it over to the Defendant; Defense expert explained request for Item 7; Court clarified that the State is to produce the hashtag numbers for the images, the logs of when and how they obtained each image they intended to use and the log for August 17, 2014 from 6:35 p.m. to 8:34 p.m.; Court advised it would set over the trial dates to April of 2016 and set the case for a two day trial
